comments:
I have a multivalued attribute of java.io.Serializable in a list allowing
several times the same value (unique=false).
For instance my list will contain the elements "A", "B", "A", "C".
I get a crash (ArrayIndexOutOffBoundsException) if I add the element "B"
using a AddCommand and then perforn an undo. Its seems the undo() method
tries to remove ALL OCCURENCES of "B" inside my list and fails because the
occurence count is bigger than the singleton collection containing the
element to remove {"B"}.
The ADD and REMOVE commands should take non unique lists into account, and work 
on elements identified by their index.
*** Bug 68460 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

The problem is in the EMF core, in NotifyingListImpl.removeAll(Collection). 
However, it reproduce it, you'll need to add an adapter to the object you're
working with.  An easy way to do it is to create an editor with
GenFeature.children=true and GenFeature.createChild=true for a 
multiplicity-many, non-unique attribute.  Create a few unique instances, and
then copy one with ctrl+dnd.  Undo, and the following exception will be thrown:

The code in question is trying to record the objects to remove and the indices
at which they occur, but it assumes that each object in the collection only
occurs once in the list.
The fixes for the common plugin are available in CVS (see bug 76290).

The requested fix for AddCommand is in CVS. Also, if the feature is unique, the
command will not be executable, rather than being executable but failing to do
anything.

RemoveCommand was also failing when an object in the collection was equal to
more than one object in the list. This is fixed, as well. Now, no more than one
object will be removed for each object in the collection, with preference given
to identical references over equal objects.

Finally, a SetCommand is now also non-executable if the feature is unique and
the new value is not.

traces.message: An exception was ignored during command execution
